application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: Pain is central to numerous clinical conditions and is the main reason that individuals seek medical treatment. Although pain involves subjective decisions and the psychophysics and neural basis of pain have been studied for decades, few have applied neuroeconomic approaches to the study of pain and its modulation. In this chapter, we provide an introduction to pain for those in the field of neuroeconomics. We focus on acute pain, which can be experimentally manipulated and studied using neuroscience tools. We first review aspects of pain-related decisions and the circuits that support different aspects of pain. We then discuss the common neural pathways that support pain and reward, as well as evidence of their interactions. Next, we introduce how pain might be viewed from a neuroeconomic perspective, focusing on the value of pain. Finally, we address hypotheses and outstanding questions for those at the intersection of pain and neuroeconomics. By providing this introduction, our goal is to inspire a new generation of studies that bridge neuroeconomics and pain to tackle critical challenges such as those brought about by the opioid epidemic.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Neuroeconomics has provided powerful insights on the brain mechanisms of decisionmaking across a wide variety of domains, including primary and secondary reinforcers [1,2], social learning and cognition [3,4], and even political preferences [5]. Although it is widely accepted that a fundamental drive for all organisms is to seek pleasure and avoid pain, and many have reviewed general relationships between pain and reward [6,7], only recently have researchers begun linking the vast literature on neuroeconomics with the diverse neuroscience of pain. We believe that this is an essential path forward and that neuroeconomic perspectives can provide important insights on pain and pain-related decision-making, similar to the recent emphasis in the field of computational psychiatry.

Reward, pain, and decision-making can interact in ways that can be either devastating (e.g., the opioid crisis) or beneficial (e.g., placebo effects). In this chapter, our goal is to address ways in which economic theory can provide insights on the clinical problem of pain and motivate those in the field of neuroeconomics to consider how their findings may be relevant for pain. We first provide an introduction to pain for those in the field of neuroeconomics, with a focus on pain-related decisions. We next address the relationship between the neural systems that support pain and reward and their interaction, laying a foundation for using economic theory to understand pain decision-making. From here, we explore how the fundamentals of neuroeconomics are relevant to the study of pain from a behavioral perspective, and highlight key studies that have evaluated the value function of pain. Finally, we discuss outstanding questions and implications of this work for future studies and the amelioration of pain and related clinical conditions.

div.head: Pain-related decision-making and relationship with neural circuits
div.p: While most of us have been asked by a clinician to rate our pain on a simple 0-10 scale ranging from "no pain" to "most pain imaginable", the psychophysics of pain and its measurement has been the subject of extensive study and debate for over 50 years. In fact, even the definition of pain remains hotly debated and regularly revised [8,9]. For the purpose of this chapter, we focus on pain as defined most recently by the International Association for the Study of Pain (IASP) [9]: "An unpleasant sensory and emotional experience associated with, or resembling that associated with, actual or potential tissue damage". Pain is different from nociception, which is defined as "The neural process of encoding and processing noxious stimuli." [8]. Thus, from an economic standpoint, nociception is most analogous to objective value, while the conscious pain experience is most related to subjective value. Like valuation and perception, the mapping between objective noxious input (e.g., temperature in thermal pain; Figure 1A) and subjective pain appears to be a nonlinear and described by a power function [10], although the exact form of the power function can differ depending on many factors, including both aspects of the noxious stimulus itself (e.g., modality, duration) and how pain is measured [11,12] . Unlike economic value, which is often evaluated with behavioral measures (e.g., choices, willingness-to-pay, etc.) and sometimes subjective ratings (e.g., desirability ratings), pain is based entirely on patients' subjective ratings. Even the revised definition of pain [9] states "A person's report of an experience as pain should be respected" while noting "Verbal description is only one of several behaviors to express pain; inability to communicate does not negate the possibility that a human or a nonhuman animal experiences pain."
We return to the measurement of pain and relationship with economic principles later in section 3.

The distinction between pain and nociception is accompanied by segregation in the central nervous system. Several studies [13][14][15] have revealed gradients within the insula and anterior cingulate cortex (ACC; Figure 1B) that map from objective nociceptive input (posterior) to subjective pain experience (anterior), and whole brain patterns have been identified that reliably predict pain, rather than nociception [16,17]. Other studies indicate that brain regions show diverse stimulus-response functions with relationship to noxious stimulus intensity and subjective pain [18,19]. Thus, the distinction between objective noxious input and subjective pain is meaningful, based on responses in the central nervous system and distinct brain circuits that respond to either noxious stimulus intensity or subjective pain.

Notably, pain is not only distinct from nociception, pain also contains two key components: intensity, which describes pain's sensory features, and unpleasantness, or the affective and motivational features of pain. Although unpleasantness and intensity are highly correlated under normal circumstances (e.g., Figure 1A), the two can be dissociated behaviorally and anatomically. For example, intensity and unpleasantness have distinct stimulus-response functions [20][21][22] and opioid analgesics [23,24], hypnosis [25], unpleasant odors [26], and some forms of meditation [27] and emotion regulation [28] can all influence pain unpleasantness while leaving pain intensity intact. Conversely, attention can alter pain intensity without affecting unpleasantness [26]. These dissociations are also present in the central nervous system. Studies generally suggest that a medial pain system (e.g. ACC, insula) is involved primarily in affective components of pain while a lateral pain system (primary and secondary somatosensory cortex) is required for sensory components of pain. Variations in unpleasantness, controlling for intensity, are correlated with activation in the ACC [29,30], while variations in intensity, controlling for unpleasantness, are associated with activation in primary somatosensory cortex (S1) [31]. ACC and insula lesions are associated with altered affective responses to pain [32,33], while patients with somatosensory lesions find noxious stimuli unpleasant without being able to localize the stimulus [34]. The mechanisms that support pain unpleasantness are likely to be shared across areas of negative affect, consistent with recent fMRI work that used machine learning to identify a brain signature to predict negative affect across modalities, including thermal pain, pressure pain, aversive sound, and aversive images [35]. Responses in midline, forebrain, insular and somatosensory regions predicted unpleasantness regardless of modality, while stimulus-specific negative affect was predicted by responses in primary and secondary sensory cortices. In the final section of this chapter, we address how future work should use neuroeconomic theory to gain insights on the functional significance of the dissociation between pain intensity and pain unpleasantness, similar to work on wanting versus liking [36,37].

Together, these studies indicate that there are important distinctions between a) pain and nociception, and b) sensory and affective components of pain, and that pain-related decision-making involves both specialized brain circuits (e.g., those that contain nociceptive neurons) and systems that are likely to be conserved across domains of negative affect. From this foundation, we now consider how neuroeconommic approaches may be useful for the study of pain.

div.head: Pain and Reward: A Common Currency?
div.p: Many brain regions involved in reward and appetitive learning and decision-making play similar roles in pain and aversive learning (for reviews, see [6,7]). In particular, dopaminergic mesolimbic / corticostriatal circuits involved in value processing, including the ventral striatum / nucleus accumbens (VS/NAc), ventromedial prefrontal cortex (VMPFC), and orbitofrontal cortex (OFC; Figure 1B), are implicated in both acute and chronic pain. Predictions about painful stimuli are associated with anticipatory responses in the VS [38][39][40][41][42][43] and VMPFC/OFC [38,40] Of course, value circuits are highly heterogeneous, and thus it is quite possible that pain and reward processing remain segregated at the level of individual neurons, even if they influence similar structures.

However, even if the neuronal underpinnings of appetitive and aversive value process-ing remain separate, there are functional interactions between pain and reward processing at the level of both brain and behavior. This bidirectional, interactive relationship is evident both in basic laboratory studies of acute and chronic pain and when we consider the high rates of anhedonia in chronic pain [44] and comorbidity between chronic pain and depression [45]. Furthermore, although we can independently manipulate pain and reward, the two are actually intrinsically linked, as pain relief is rewarding (i.e. negative reinforcement; for review, see [46]). Relief can be operationalized experimentally as transient relief from tonic pain [43], responses at pain offset [47,48], or relative relief based on the context surrounding pain (i.e. receiving a moderately painful stimulus when expecting high pain [49,50]. In healthy volunteers, pain relief is associated with activation in the VS and OFC/VMPFC [43,[47][48][49][50]. Relative to healthy volunteers, people with chronic pain show reduced responses to pain offset in the NAc [47] and the dopaminergic ventral tegmental area (VTA) [51]. Animal models confirm that pain offset engages VTA dopamine neurons [52] and dopamine release in the NAc shell [53] and that inhibiting VTA dopamine prevents relief-related conditioned place preference [54]. Notably, reward is also associated with relief via analgesic treatments: Healthy individuals who report higher trait reward responsivity experience stronger opioid analgesia [55], and individuals who show stronger NAc responses to monetary reward experience stronger placebo analgesia and have higher placebo-induced dopamine binding in the VS [56].

Together this work highlights the many ways in which pain and reward are intrinsically linked. From this foundation, we now turn to direct consideration of how the basic tenets of neuroeconomics have the potential to lead to new insights in our understanding of pain.

div.head: Neuroeconomic Approaches and their Utility to the Study of Pain
div.p: Two main aspects of neuroeconomic theory are particularly helpful in conceptualizing decision-making in the context of pain and reward. First, value serves as a unifying signal for decision-making because it straddles both ends of the valence dimension (see Box 1).

In other words, value is not only reward. The value of a stimulus or an action can be negative when the outcome is a loss and positive when the outcome is a gain. While most outcomes in behavioral economics studies are monetary losses and gains, the results from these studies could be generalized to aversive outcomes like pain when conceptualized as a loss or diminishment in well-being. Moreover, appetitive and aversive outcome values may be integrated through a cost-benefit computation into a net decision value [57]. A unified monotonic value signal has been consistently found to be encoded in the VMPFC and anterior part of VS [58,59]. Critically, the brain's valuation signal in VMPFC appears to be invariant to the specific type of good or outcome that is evaluated [60,61] (from monetary to consummatory rewards or consumer goods), while OFC seems to preserve information about the specific identity of the outcome [62][63][64]. This evaluation happens automatically even in the absence of a behavioral output or an overt choice, such as when passively viewing stimuli [65,66].

The second aspect is that neuroeconomics rests on the premise that the brain "transforms" the objective value of the stimuli or options available (for example, monetary rewards or consummable goods) into a subjective value representation, which is used for decision-making. This is relevant to pain because it is also characterized by a subjective experience that is distinct from the objective parameters of the painful stimulus itself, such as its intensity or nature. The mapping between objective and subjective value is referred to in neuroeconomics as the utility function and is central to understanding both individual differences in decision-making and to making predictions about choice 10 behavior under uncertainty (Box 1). Drawing parallels between pain and reward-related decision-making is possible and application of approaches from neuroeconomics, as we will discuss below, have started to expand our understanding of the similarities and differences between the two. The shape of this utility function for pain has implications for decision-making under risk (see Box 1). A concave utility function means that the expected utility (probability * utility) of a lottery is significantly lower than the utility of its expected value (probability * objective value), leading to the preference of a smaller more certain offer over a higher riskier one. Conversely, convexity is equivalent to the presence of risk-seeking preferences. As follows, a convex pain value function would predict that the individual is willing to take risk in order to avoid pain. Interestingly, while the outcomes in the Slimani et al. study were not probabilistic, the curvature of the pain value function they derived suggests a tendency for risk aversion for pain (willingness to accept some pain with certainty but avoid options that could lead to more pain with some probability < 1).

div.head: The Value of Pain
div.p: While nonlinearities have also been described for the utility function for monetary losses (Box 1, panel B), risk tolerance rather than risk aversion has been typically observed for monetary reinforcers. Few empirical studies have directly investigated the shape of the utility function for pain, but there is evidence that risk preferences may vary depending on the attribute of pain (intensity versus duration in a cold-pressor task) [70], with individuals exhibiting risk aversion (concave function) for pain intensity but risk seeking (convex function) based on pain duration. This divergence has been considered in prior work that posits that the additional affective value of a reinforcer (such as pain) could be a separate input into the decision, thereby biasing it from its purely cognitive value [71,72].

There is also evidence that risk preferences for pain may vary depending on the object of pain, with individuals being more risk averse when pain is to be experienced by a stranger compared to themselves or their loved ones [73], contrary to what has been reported for Consistent with other predictions from the neuroeconomic framework, the pain value function seems to be affected by monetary range (reward context) [69], such that availability of larger rewards decreased the willingness to accept pain offers that were previously tolerated and accepted. This feature of pain valuation recapitulates predictions from the efficient coding hypothesis, how optimal neuronal encoding according to reward availability in the environment leads to contextual changes in valuation, a phenomenon known as range adaptation [74,75]. That reward context impacts the pain value function in this way further supports the notion that pain and reward interact and are integrated into a cost-benefit computation that guides choice behavior [68]. Range adaptation and another contextual mechanism known as reference-dependence (Box 1) have been proposed to explain irrational decision-making behavior [76] and have been identified in previous studies of appetitive and aversive value learning [77].

It is also possible to conceptualize the presence of pain as affecting the sensitivity to reward. This is consistent with the phenomenon of reference-dependence as described in Prospect Theory (Box 1, Panel B). Pain could thus shift the frame of reference to a worse state of the world. A leftward shift in the utility function could lead to a relative change in the utility perceived to be derived from the same reward [78,79], potentially increasing reward seeking. Several studies have explored the effect of acute pain on economic choice and identified a tendency for acute pain to lead to increase in risk tolerance and delay discounting [80][81][82]. Moreover, individuals with chronic pain exhibit difficulties in distinguishing high versus low risk [83] and have an increased preference for immediate rewards [84][85][86]. One study has reported that a prospective procedure aimed at reducing delay discounting-episodic future thinking-may be lower pain severity in chronic pain patients through a decrease in impulsive decision-making [87]. The neural mechanisms of these pain-induced shifts in reward related behavior are not known. One possibility is that pain is impacting the valuation itself through a sort of gain modulation, as has been posited for other internal states such as craving [88]. Future work could address this question by combining careful neuroeconomic modeling combined with brain measures of valuation. While Prospect Theory's prediction of a "reflection effect" for monetary outcomes (concavity for gains and convexity for losses) seems to generalize to feelings [90], the pain utility function described in panel A (right) does not show the same pattern.

The shape of the pain function indicates that willingness-to-accept decreases with each increase in pain level (more and more money is needed to accept). Individuals thus seem to exhibit risk aversion for experienced pain level [70,91]. Second, while the distinction between pain and nociception might parallel the mapping between value and subjective value, how can we think of the distinction between intensity and unpleasantness in the realm of pain? If pain value can be indirectly linked to intensity (through subjective pain ratings, for example), is the derived value function also capturing unpleasantness or the hedonic aspect of pain? Neuroeconomics has encountered a similar dichotomy in thinking about the difference between "wanting" versus "linking" a reward [36,95]. Just as pain intensity and unpleasantness can be uncorrelated, a reinforcer can be intensely "wanted" but not necessarily "liked", or vice versa. Clinical examples of this difference are often seen in individuals with chronic substance disorders whose drug consumption is sought (wanted) despite no longer leading to a positive hedonic experience [96]. Neuroeconomists have proposed this divergence can be resolved through multiple utility functions [97] or posited "liking" as an early stage of value learning [37], but this remains an issue of active inquiry and interest in the field. Finally, given the interrelated nature of pain relief and reward, it is fruitful to measure how interventions that specifically target pain unpleasantness, such as opioid analgesics, impact economic decisions.

Mu-opioid receptor activation has been shown to increase choices for high-value / highprobability targets [98], and individuals receiving treatment for opioid use disorder with medications such as buprenorphine or methadone become more tolerant of uncertainty prior to a reuse event [99]. More research is needed in bridging the neuroeconomics of pain relief and that of of opioid addiction.

The devastating consequences of the opioid use disorder epidemic in the United States and the lack of tangible solutions for the safe treatment of chronic pain conditions have made more urgent the call for progress in this research. Similar to recent efforts in computational psychiatry that apply neuroeconomics and computational neuroscience frameworks to clinical problems in mental health, a new generation of studies should use these methods to advance our understanding of pain and pain-related behaviors.

figure.head: Figure 1 .
figure.figDesc: Pain psychophysics and associated brain pathways. A. Top: Studies of acute pain use specialized devices to deliver noxious stimuli. Here, a thermode delivers heat at different temperatures to a participant's forearm. Bottom: Participants are asked to rate pain in response to changes in noxious stimulus intensity. This figure depicts example data from a healthy participant who separately rated the intensity and unpleasantness of an 8-second thermal pain stimulus applied to the forearm at different temperatures. Both aspects of pain are fit with a power function. B. Cortical regions such as the anterior cingulate cortex and the insula differentiate between subjective pain (purple) and noxious input (red). Regions involved in subjective pain overlap with those involved in pain affect and affective processing more generally. In addition, targets of dopamine pathways such as the ventral striatum and the ventromedial prefrontal cortex (VMPFC) and orbitofrontal cortex (OFC) are involved in updating predictions about pain, similar to their role in error-driven reward learning. C. Traditional reward networks exhibit activation during anticipation of pain. Top: The ventral striatum and VMPFC show elevated activation in response to cues that predict high pain, relative to low pain (reprinted with permission from [38]). Bottom: The ventral striatum also shows elevated activation in response to conditioned cues that predict unpleasant electric shocks relative to neutral cues (reprinted with permission from [39]). Figure created in part using biorender.com.

figure.head: Figure 1 .
figure.figDesc: Pain psychophysics and associated brain pathways. A. Top: Studies of acute pain use specialized devices to deliver noxious stimuli. Here, a thermode delivers heat at different temperatures to a participant's forearm. Bottom: Participants are asked to rate pain in response to changes in noxious stimulus intensity. This figure depicts example data from a healthy participant who separately rated the intensity and unpleasantness of an 8-second thermal pain stimulus applied to the forearm at different temperatures. Both aspects of pain are fit with a power function. B. Cortical regions such as the anterior cingulate cortex and the insula differentiate between subjective pain (purple) and noxious input (red). Regions involved in subjective pain overlap with those involved in pain affect and affective processing more generally. In addition, targets of dopamine pathways such as the ventral striatum and the ventromedial prefrontal cortex (VMPFC) and orbitofrontal cortex (OFC) are involved in updating predictions about pain, similar to their role in error-driven reward learning. C. Traditional reward networks exhibit activation during anticipation of pain. Top: The ventral striatum and VMPFC show elevated activation in response to cues that predict high pain, relative to low pain (reprinted with permission from Atlas 2010). Bottom: The ventral striatum also shows elevated activation in response to conditioned cues that predict unpleasant electric shocks relative to neutral cues (reprinted with permission from Jensen 2003). Figure created in part using biorender.com.

and value signals and prediction errors in these regions update during aversive learning in ways that are consistent with quantitative models of reinforcement learning [40-43], similar to reward learning. Studies that compare pain with monetary reward indicate that the VS responds similarly to the anticipation of pain and reward while the OFC and anterior insula seem to separately code valence [40].

Using a neuroeconomics approach to the study of pain implies inferring the subjective valuation process by presenting the decision-maker with options of varying objective value.Park et al.[67] directly derived a participant-specific stimulus-response function by fitting a power model to pain ratings obtained as participants received shocks of increasing intensity. They found the shape of the objective stimulus to subjective experience function to be nonlinear , such that increases in the intensity of the pain stimulus lead toexponentially increasing perceived pain (Box 1, panel A, left). Using this function to personalize the pairing of monetary reward and pain, they tested different subjective value models against behavior and neural activity in VMPFC, OFC, and subgenual ACC. In all cases, the best model was one that performed a nonlinear integration of reward and pain. Evidence of pain and reward value integration as a cost-benefit computation has also been reported in the ACC and VS, such that these areas' responses to reward were attenuated in the presence of pain [68]. More recently, Slimani at al. [69] used the same approach as Park et al. [67] to personalize painful stimuli according to the participantderived stimulus-response function, and created trials that tiled the space between pain detection and tolerance thresholds . They then evaluated the participants' willingness to accept monetary rewards paired with different levels of painful electrical stimulation, and estimated the utility function of pain from the points of indifference (50% probability of accepting a specific offer of combined monetary reward and pain). The best pain utility model was a quadratic function of experienced pain level (Box 1, panel A, right).

monetary outcomes. More research is needed to resolve to what extend there are general or distinct mechanisms of valuation for aversive outcomes of different modalities such as primary (e.g. pain) and secondary (e.g. monetary losses) reinforcers, and how affective and social factors modulate these valuation processes.

Conclusions and Future DirectionsThe central thesis that avoiding pain and procuring reward as two essential motivators of animal behavior is present in philosophy, economics, and neuroscience. In the utilitarian theory advanced by Jeremy Bentham, the pains and pleasures we experience should not only be quantifiable, but most importantly, contribute jointly to constructing the organizing force of behavior-utility[92]. Recent behavioral and neural studies have started to test the limits of this old idea, and begun to paint a more complex picture of interrelated affective and cognitive processes involved in pain-related decision-making.Several open questions remain. First, given the focus of neuroeconomics on choice behavior should pain research adopt behavioral rather than self-reported measures of pain for the development of objective biomarkers? A similar discussion emerged in the field of psychiatry recently, which has had to wrestle with poor correlation between self-report scales and task-based behavioral measures, and worse prediction of real-world outcomes from behavior compared to self-report[93,94]. Rather than task-based behavioral measures replacing self-report, they may complement each other, by providing different sources of information. Research is needed to disambiguate what each type of measure is useful for.
